name: Tuesday Afternoon on Delivery Suite
description: A busy Tuesday afternoon on the Delivery Suite with seven women on the board. Three require urgent assessment: one presents with vomiting and malaise (concealed DKA), another with sudden PV bleeding, and a third with reduced fetal movements. The remaining four are progressing normally but still need monitoring. Prioritise based on clinical urgency.
briefing: It's a busy Tuesday afternoon on the Delivery Suite. There are seven women on the board. Three need your urgent attention: one has been vomiting and feeling unwell, another has had a sudden PV bleed, and a third is worried about reduced fetal movements. Four other women are progressing normally in labour or postnatal care. You need to assess, investigate, and manage each patient appropriately. Remember to prioritise based on clinical urgency.

patients.name: Sarah Mitchell
patients.presentingComplaint: Vomiting for 2 days, generalised abdominal pain, feels generally unwell. Partner says she's been drinking a lot of water recently.
patients.history: Sarah was sent in by her community midwife after reporting 2 days of persistent vomiting, abdominal pain, and general malaise. She mentions increased thirst and frequent urination over the past week. No PV bleeding or loss. Fetal movements felt but reduced from normal.
patients.pmh: No significant medical history. No known diabetes. BMI 31 at booking. Family history of Type 2 diabetes (mother).
patients.initialCtg: Baseline 150bpm, variability 10-15bpm, no accelerations, no decelerations. Contractions: irregular tightenings.

patients.name: Lisa Thompson
patients.presentingComplaint: PV bleeding — sudden 'gush' approximately 20 minutes ago. Soaked through pad.
patients.history: Lisa self-presented to Delivery Suite after a sudden gush of PV bleeding at home. She describes bright red blood soaking through one pad. No pain initially but now reports mild lower abdominal discomfort. Baby moving well.
patients.pmh: Previous LSCS x1 (2019, breech), SVD x1 (2021). Low-lying placenta noted at 20-week scan but reported as clear at 32-week rescan. Gestational hypertension this pregnancy — on labetalol 200mg BD.
patients.initialCtg: Baseline 145bpm, variability 5-10bpm (reduced), occasional accelerations, no decelerations.

patients.name: Emma Williams
patients.presentingComplaint: Hasn't felt baby move since yesterday morning. Very anxious.
patients.history: Emma called triage this morning reporting reduced fetal movements since yesterday. She has been busy at work and isn't sure if she might have missed movements. She felt some movement after a cold drink this morning but 'not as much as usual'. Otherwise feels well.
patients.pmh: No significant medical history. Straightforward pregnancy. Low-risk.
patients.initialCtg: Baseline 135bpm, variability 15-25bpm, accelerations present, no decelerations. Reactive trace.

patients.name: Priya Patel
patients.presentingComplaint: In established labour, contracting 3 in 10. Progressing well.
patients.history: Priya was admitted 4 hours ago in spontaneous labour. ARM performed at 5cm, clear liquor. Now 7cm on last VE 1 hour ago. Coping well with entonox. Previous SVD 2022, no complications.
patients.pmh: No significant medical history. Straightforward pregnancy.
patients.initialCtg: Baseline 140bpm, variability 10-25bpm, accelerations present, no decelerations. Normal trace.

patients.name: Jenny Adams
patients.presentingComplaint: Post-dates induction. Syntocinon commenced 2 hours ago.
patients.history: Jenny was admitted yesterday for post-dates induction. Propess inserted yesterday, ARM this morning with clear liquor. Syntocinon started 2 hours ago, currently on 6ml/hr. Contracting 2 in 10, mild. Last VE: 3cm dilated.
patients.initialCtg: Baseline 145bpm, variability 10-15bpm, no accelerations, no decelerations. Satisfactory trace.

patients.name: Maria Santos
patients.presentingComplaint: Raised BP at clinic. Admitted for monitoring and steroids.
patients.history: Maria was referred from antenatal clinic with BP 148/95. She reports mild headache but no visual disturbance, epigastric pain, or clonus. Urine dip: protein 1+. Bloods sent including pre-eclampsia screen. First dose of betamethasone given. On magnesium sulphate observation chart.
patients.pmh: Gestational hypertension in previous pregnancy (2020). Two previous SVDs, no complications.
patients.initialCtg: Baseline 138bpm, variability 10-15bpm, occasional accelerations, no decelerations.

patients.name: Hannah Clarke
patients.presentingComplaint: Postnatal — SVD 2 hours ago. Awaiting checks and discharge.
patients.history: Hannah delivered a healthy boy (3.6kg) by SVD 2 hours ago. Physiological third stage, intact perineum. EBL 250ml. Breastfeeding initiated. Baby well, Apgar 9/10 at 1 and 5 minutes. Awaiting postnatal observations and newborn checks before discharge.
patients.pmh: No significant medical history. Previous SVD 2023, straightforward.

payload.message: The ketone meter has been taken to A&E — not currently available on the unit.
The coordinator asks if anyone can help in Room 4 — another woman is in advanced labour.
A ketone meter has been found and returned to the unit.
The lab has phoned — there's a delay on blood results. Expected wait now 20 minutes.
